questions.text: Which data structure uses LIFO (Last In, First Out) principle?
questions.explanation: A stack is a linear data structure that follows the LIFO principle - the last element added is the first one to be removed.

questions.text: What is the time complexity of searching for an element in a balanced binary search tree?
questions.explanation: In a balanced binary search tree, each comparison eliminates roughly half of the remaining tree, resulting in logarithmic time complexity.

questions.text: When implementing a hash table, what is a good approach to handle collisions?
questions.explanation: Linear probing is a collision resolution technique where we sequentially search for the next available slot in the hash table.

questions.text: What is the time complexity of Bubble Sort in the worst case?
questions.explanation: Bubble Sort uses nested loops, comparing adjacent elements and swapping them if they're in the wrong order.

questions.text: Which algorithm is commonly used for finding the shortest path in a weighted graph?
questions.explanation: Dijkstra's Algorithm is specifically designed to find the shortest path between nodes in a graph with non-negative edge weights.

questions.text: What is the maximum number of comparisons needed to find an element in a sorted array of size n using binary search?
questions.explanation: Binary search halves the search space with each comparison, resulting in a worst-case of log₂(n) comparisons.

questions.text: Which of the following is an example of supervised learning?
questions.explanation: Classification is a supervised learning task where the model learns to assign labels to input data based on labeled training examples.

questions.text: What is the purpose of regularization in machine learning models?
questions.explanation: Regularization adds a penalty term to the loss function to discourage the model from learning overly complex patterns that don't generalize well.
